proposals.reasoning: This lineup matches the emerging consensus and keeps the first mission simple and readable. Alice and Frank are commonly seen as transparent early‑game picks, and adding Grace follows the preference several players voiced (with Henry as the only real alternative). Starting with this trio avoids stacking too many strong talkers, gives us a calm baseline for information, and doesn’t auto‑clear anyone even if the mission succeeds.

votes.comment: Standard, consensus early team with me plus two generally readable players; good for baseline info and nothing screams coordinated evil yet.
Standard, broadly agreed-on M1 team with no strong red flags; good to get early info without overcomplicating.
Both known evils (Eve, Henry) are off the team; this is a solid, low-risk Mission 1 lineup consistent with table consensus.
Standard, broadly agreed-on M1 team with generally readable players; fine to take early info here as long as we don’t hard-clear on a single success.
Evil is on the team already and the table broadly supports this lineup, so it’s good for us to let it go through.
I like being on the first mission with a generally trusted-looking trio; I can play it safe here and build credibility for later missions.
Solid consensus, includes me for direct info, and a clean Mission 1 (success or fail) gives useful early reads without auto-clearing anyone.
Good first mission for evil with one known teammate on it and no reason to disrupt the apparent consensus.

discussion.content: Early on I’d rather keep it simple: I’m happy to go, and I’d lean toward including one of Charlie/Frank (who usually play pretty transparently) plus someone we haven’t seen drive the table too hard yet, rather than stacking strong talkers like Diana/Eve right away.

I’m fine with keeping it straightforward here: I’d like at least one of Charlie/Frank on the first team, and between the “quieter” picks I slightly prefer adding Grace or Henry over piling on strong voices like Diana/Eve right away.

I like the idea of starting with people who tend to be readable, so I’m comfortable with something like Alice + Frank plus one of Grace/Henry rather than loading up on the loudest voices right away. Early clean info from a calmer team is more useful than a flashy first mission.

I’m okay staying off the very first team, but I’d like at least one of Alice/Frank plus one of Grace/Henry so we get a relatively “readable” trio without overcommitting to the same core later as auto‑trusted.
I’m good staying off this one; from what’s been said, Alice + Frank + Grace feels like a solid, readable starting trio, and we can re-evaluate around that info afterward.

I’m fine with me on the first team, and between the options I slightly prefer Alice + me + Grace as a starting trio. If people are uneasy about that, swapping Grace for Henry seems like the only other sensible tweak.

I’m okay with Alice + Frank + me as a starting point, but I’d like us to treat even a success there as “provisionally good” rather than auto-clearing that core so we don’t get locked into the same trio later. If people are uneasy about that setup, I’d swap me for Henry rather than breaking up Alice/Frank.

Alice + Frank + Grace feels like a reasonable starting point to me, and I’d rather not overcomplicate Mission 1 as long as we all agree a single success doesn’t hard-clear anyone. If people are nervous about Grace, I’d only swap in me or Charlie, not break up Alice/Frank.

proposals.reasoning: We get strong continuity from the fully successful Mission 1 by keeping the proven core of Alice, Frank, and Grace together, which most people have expressed comfort with, while adding exactly one new player—Charlie—to generate fresh information without overhauling the team. This balances preserving our best-known trust so far with testing a single new variable, and it aligns with the majority of table suggestions favoring a M1-based core plus Charlie as the cleanest incremental step.

votes.comment: Keeps the fully successful M1 core together and adds exactly one new variable (Charlie), which is the safest info-gaining step without overhauling what already worked.

M1’s Alice/Frank/Grace core is likely mostly good, and adding exactly one new player (Charlie) is a reasonable low-variance info step; rejecting just burns a proposal without a clearly better alternative.
Keeps the entire clean M1 core together and adds just one new player, which is a low-risk way to both preserve trust and get fresh info without over-reshuffling.
I don’t like auto-keeping all three from M1; I’d rather run a 2-from-core team (e.g., Alice/Frank plus two new) to get clearer info instead of re-locking the entire first group.
Team is close enough to the successful M1 core that I’m fine testing it with just one new variable in Charlie for now.
I’m on the team and can keep the trusted M1 core intact while introducing just one new variable, which is a reasonable balance for Mission 2.
Keeps the entire successful Mission 1 core and adds just one new variable (Charlie), which is the safest info-gain while preserving our strongest trust so far.
Keeps the full clean M1 core together while only adding one new variable in Charlie, which is a reasonable low-chaos way to build on a proven success and gather more info.

discussion.content: I’d like to keep at least two from the successful first team—so I’m leaning toward something like me, Frank, Grace plus one of Charlie or Henry, since we get to test new info without throwing out what already worked.

I like anchoring on the Mission 1 crew too; Alice and Frank both feel fine to keep. Between Charlie and Henry I’d slightly rather test Charlie here, just so we’re not clustering all the quiet reads on the bench again.

I’m good with sticking close to the M1 core too—Alice, Frank, Grace all look fine so far—and between the new adds I’d rather see Charlie here than Henry so we’re not risking too many unknowns at once.

I like keeping two from the first mission but I don’t think we should auto-lock all three, so I’d rather see something like Alice, Frank, Charlie, Henry to both preserve some trust and get a cleaner read on the new additions.

I don’t love auto-keeping all three from M1 either—statistically there’s a decent chance we had 1 evil on that team—so I’d rather see something like Alice, Frank, Henry plus one of Charlie/Grace to both preserve some trust and actually learn something new.

I’m with the idea of not auto-locking all three from M1—keeping two feels safer—so I’d lean toward something like Alice, me, plus one of Grace/Charlie and one of Henry/Charlie so we’re both preserving trust and actually generating new info.

I get not auto-locking all three from M1, but tossing out two of us feels like wasting a clean success, so I’d like to see something like Alice, Frank, me, and Charlie this round. That keeps a solid core while giving us one fresh read instead of reshuffling almost everything.

I’m with the “don’t over-correct from a clean M1” camp—keeping Alice and Frank feels right, and I’d rather just add one fresh slot, so something like Alice, Frank, Grace, and me keeps a strong core while only introducing one new variable.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 2 failed when only Charlie was added to the Mission 1 team of Alice, Frank, and me, so the most suspicious block is {Alice, Frank, Grace, Charlie}. As a known-good to myself, I want to hard-test the rest of the table by taking a fully 'outsider' team that completely avoids that block. Choosing Bob, Diana, Eve, and Henry maximizes information: if this mission fails, we know at least one evil sits in the outsiders; if it succeeds, suspicion concentrates heavily back on {Alice, Frank, Charlie} (from my perspective), giving us a much clearer structure for missions 4 and 5.

votes.comment: Full outsider test is fine in theory, but excluding me while adding Eve instead of using the broadly-liked core of Alice+Bob and one or two outsiders feels like unnecessary risk and misrepresents how suspicious I should be given Mission 1’s clean result.
Full outsider test is logically strong after Mission 2’s fail; this cleanly isolates the Alice/Frank/Grace/Charlie block for future reads and doesn’t obviously over-stack suspects here.
Too risky to run a 4-person mission with both Eve and Henry while leaving Alice off entirely; I’d rather stick to an Alice/Bob core plus at most one from the F/G/C block.
Full outsider team best isolates the Mission 2 fail onto {Alice, Frank, Grace, Charlie}; strong info either way and still acceptable risk at 1–1.
Two evils on the team gives us strong control over the mission outcome and keeps suspicion focused on the other block.
Two evils on this team gives us a strong chance to sabotage while keeping blame diffuse between outsider vs prior-block narratives.
Full outsider test gives maximum info and cleanly isolates the Mission 2 fail away from me; I’m happy to sit out and learn where the evil cluster is.
Still fits the outsider-test idea and keeps the whole Mission 2 block off, which should give strong info either way.

discussion.content: Given Mission 1 was clean and Mission 2 only added Charlie, I think there’s exactly one evil in {Frank, Grace, Charlie}, so for this team I’d really like to see me plus mostly “outsiders” like Bob and Henry, with at most one of F/G/C.
I broadly like Alice’s logic: I’d lean toward a team of Alice, me, Henry, plus just one of {Frank, Grace, Charlie}, and I’d especially avoid putting both Frank and Grace on the same team right now.
I’m on board with Alice/Bob as a core, but I’d much rather see Diana in this mix than Henry or Eve, and then just one of {Frank, Grace, Charlie} so we don’t double-dip into the suspicious group.
I’m happiest with a mostly “outsider” team here: something like Alice, Bob, me, and Henry, completely off the Frank/Grace/Charlie block to hard-test whether the problem is in that group.
I like the “outsiders” angle, but I’d actually go Alice, Bob, me, and Henry so we keep completely off the Frank/Grace/Charlie block and see if that clears up where the Mission 2 fail came from.

If we’re serious about testing whether the problem is in {Frank, Grace, Charlie}, then a completely “outsider” team like Alice, Bob, Eve, and Henry makes the most sense to me, and I’m fine sitting out so we get a cleaner read.

Given I know I’m good, the Mission 2 fail points me toward Frank or Charlie (or a wild Alice hit), so I’d rather we hard-test the “outsiders” with something like Alice, Bob, Diana, and Henry and leave all of {Frank, me, Charlie} off this one.
I’d back a full “outsider” test here with Alice, Bob, Eve, and me, completely leaving {Frank, Grace, Charlie} off so if this one passes we basically know the Mission 2 problem sits in that block.

proposals.reasoning: Most of the table has converged on building Mission 4 around the Mission 1/2 core of {Alice, Frank, Grace, Charlie}, and multiple people have explicitly supported that structure. Given the double-fail on Mission 3, we should limit ourselves to at most one player from {Bob, Diana, Eve, Henry}. Among that group, several players (Bob and Frank in particular) have indicated that I look slightly safer than the others, and I’ve already said that if we’re dipping back into the Mission 3 pool I’d be willing to be that fifth. This team follows the majority preference of using the established core while adding only a single member from the risky set, and Henry is the shaded-pool choice with the most stated lean support, so this lineup is the most likely to be broadly acceptable while still respecting the group’s structural reasoning.

votes.comment: Including all four of {Alice, Frank, Grace, Charlie} guarantees at least one evil on the team given the Mission 3 math; we should take only three from that core plus one from {Bob, Diana, Eve, Henry} instead.

I know I’m good, so the 2+ evils from Mission 3 are all in {Diana, Eve, Henry}. That makes Henry quite likely evil, and both potential Merlins (Charlie/Eve) have been leaning me over Henry as the safer pick. This team is very likely to include an evil with Henry on it.

We know there’s exactly one evil among {Alice, Frank, Grace, Charlie}, so adding Henry from the double-fail pool still risks putting 2 evils on the team; I’d rather see a different fifth or even re-examine which three from the core we trust most.

Math says there is exactly 1 evil in {Alice, Frank, Grace, Charlie} and 2 in {Bob, Diana, Eve, Henry}, so this team (4 from core + Henry) is guaranteed to contain at least 1 evil; we should take 3 from core + 1 from Mission 3 group instead.
It follows the broadly agreed structure: the Mission 1/2 core plus exactly one from the Mission 3 group, and Henry has been slightly town-leaned by several people.
This follows the consensus core plus only one from the Mission 3 group, and Henry still looks like the least-bad option from that pool to me.

By the mission results there is exactly 1 evil in {Alice, Frank, Grace, Charlie} and 2 in {Bob, Diana, Eve, Henry}. This team locks in all four core (guaranteeing 1 evil) plus Henry from the evil-heavy pool, making 2-evil team too likely. I prefer 3 from the core + 1 from {Bob, Diana, Eve, Henry} we trust most.
It’s not my ideal 3-from-core-plus-1 structure, but this follows the table’s preferred core and only adds one from the Mission 3 pool, so I’m willing to back it.

proposals.reasoning:
From mission results we know there is exactly one evil among {Alice, Frank, Grace, Charlie} and exactly two evils among {Bob, Diana, Eve, Henry}. To build a clean team of 5, we have to (1) correctly exclude the single evil from the core and (2) correctly pick the two goods from the mission 3 pool.

1) Choosing the core subset:
- I know Alice is good (I’m Alice).
- Grace’s combinatorial point that we *shouldn’t* auto-take all four of {Alice, Frank, Grace, Charlie} is logically sound from a good perspective; that leans her good.
- Charlie has been widely trusted and was only on the 1-fail mission 2 team, which doesn’t single him out strongly as evil.
- Frank, by contrast, led the failing mission 2 and pushed for including all four core members for mission 4, which ignores the guaranteed "exactly one evil in the core" structure. That’s more suspicious.
=> I exclude Frank as the likeliest evil in {Alice, Frank, Grace, Charlie} and keep Alice, Grace, and Charlie as the core.

2) Choosing from the mission 3 pool {Bob, Diana, Eve, Henry}:
We must add two players from this group. There are exactly two evils here, so we need to avoid them.
- Eve and Diana both feel more suspect: they were on the double-fail mission and are each arguing themselves as preferable picks in a way that can be read as positioning.
- Bob and Henry are more broadly treated as the "less bad" options: multiple players independently floated Bob as the safest from that set; Frank (despite my suspicion of him) tagged Henry as his least-bad option; Henry’s own structure of wanting {Alice, Grace, Charlie} is consistent with a good read of the core, even if self-advocacy is NAI.
Given limited information and needing two from this pool, the best odds alignment-wise is to assume the evils here are {Diana, Eve} and therefore select Bob and Henry as the likely goods.

Result: Team = {Alice, Bob, Charlie, Grace, Henry}, built on (1) excluding the most suspicious core member (Frank) and (2) taking the two least-suspected members from the mission 3 group (Bob, Henry) under the constraint that exactly two in that group are evil.

votes.comment: Best use of info: we must exclude one from {Alice, Frank, Grace, Charlie} and two from {Bob, Diana, Eve, Henry}; Frank is the shadiest core member after leading the M2 fail and pushing all four core despite Grace’s correct combinatorial point, and Bob/Henry are the least-bad bets from the Mission 3 pool.

Given my info, Merlin is almost certainly Charlie, making Charlie good. Then the single core evil in {Alice, Frank, Grace, Charlie} is most likely Frank, who is excluded here. From {Diana, Eve, Henry} exactly two are evil; Eve is very likely evil (fake Merlin), so it’s between Diana/Henry, and Diana looks worse. This team is our best shot at a clean 5.
I’m not comfortable taking two people from the Mission 3 fail, and Henry in particular hasn’t done enough to clear himself after being on that double-fail team.

I know I’m good and there are exactly two evils in {Bob, Diana, Eve, Henry}, so at least one of Bob/Henry is evil; combined with exactly one evil in {Alice, Frank, Grace, Charlie} and all of Alice/Grace/Charlie on this team, this lineup is almost certainly dirty from my POV.
Composition fits the combinatorial constraints reasonably well and avoids the most suspicious configurations from the Mission 3 group; worth testing.
Only one suspected-evil from the Mission 3 pool (Henry) is on this team, so it’s very unlikely to double-fail; I’d rather take this and sort things out for Mission 5.
I know I’m good; since there is exactly one evil in {Alice, Frank, Grace, Charlie}, taking both Alice and Charlie with me guarantees that evil is on this team.
This team can contain at most one evil from the Mission 3 pool, which makes Mission 4 structurally safe for good (needs two fails), so as evil I don’t want this to go.

proposals.reasoning: We know from the double-fail on Mission 3 that there are exactly two evils among {Bob, Diana, Eve, Henry}, and from Mission 2’s single fail that there is exactly one evil among {Alice, Frank, Grace, Charlie}. Including all four of the Mission 2 core would guarantee at least one evil, so I’m deliberately taking only three from that group. Grace’s point about the math of the cores was very town-leaning, and Charlie has been consistently treated as a stabilizing presence, so I’m prioritizing Charlie and Grace as likely good. Between Alice and Frank as the remaining core slots, I’m choosing Alice this time to avoid fully replicating the failed Mission 2 team and to keep Frank off for information and safety. From the Mission 3 pool, I’m including myself (I know I’m good) and then, based on table sentiment and comparative suspicion, Henry has been read as slightly safer than Diana or Eve by multiple players. This gives us a 3-from-core/2-from-Mission-3 structure that avoids guaranteed evil from the core and tries to stack the Mission 3 picks toward the least-suspected options while not repeating the exact failing team from Mission 2 or loading up on the most-contested Mission 3 players.

votes.comment: This team best balances the hard constraints: 3 from the Mission 2 core (where there’s exactly 1 evil among 4) and 2 from the Mission 3 pool while avoiding the most-suspected Diana/Eve and leaving Frank off in case he’s the core evil. There’s a plausible world where all 5 are good, and given prior discussion this is about as reasonable as we’re likely to get before we run out of proposals.

Given my info, I know I’m good, and I strongly lean that Eve is evil, making Henry more likely to be the single good in {Diana, Eve, Henry}. Keeping Eve and Diana off while excluding one core member (likely Frank as the evil there) gives a plausible all-good team, so I’m willing to take this shot at a must-succeed mission.
Still too much risk from the Mission 3 pool; Henry was on the double-fail team and I don’t want any of that group here when we only need one more fail to lose.

Given I’m good, there are exactly two evils among {Bob, Eve, Henry}; this team includes Bob and Henry plus exactly one evil from {Alice, Frank, Grace, Charlie}, so it guarantees at least two evils on the mission.
Only one evil (Henry) on this team, so quest 4 would almost certainly succeed and give good a tie and more info. As evil, I want at least two evils on the team to close the game now.
One of the more consistent logical builds given the mission constraints; I’m fine sending this for the information it gives.

Henry’s first proposal knowingly guaranteed at least one evil from the core, which makes him suspicious, and this team still includes both him and Bob from the double-fail pool where we know exactly two evils sit. I don’t trust this specific 3+2 combination enough to risk the game on it.
Fits the 3-from-core/2-from-Mission-3 logic, avoids the guaranteed-evil full core, and keeps the shadiest Mission 3 players off while not repeating the exact failing Mission 2 team.

proposals.reasoning: We know from the Mission 3 double-fail that there are exactly two evils in {Bob, Diana, Eve, Henry}, and from that plus the earlier results there must be exactly one evil in {Alice, Frank, Grace, Charlie}. Since Mission 4 needs *two* FAIL cards to fail, having at most one suspected player on the team is acceptable. I’m building this team to (1) completely avoid the pair that currently look worst from the Mission 3 group, Eve and Henry, and (2) still not lock in all of {Alice, Frank, Grace, Charlie}, which would guarantee exactly one evil among them. Alice has been the most insistent on including all four of that core despite that guaranteeing an evil, which I’m not comfortable with, so I’m leaving her off. That gives a team of three from the core (Charlie, Frank, Grace) plus the two least-bad options from the Mission 3 pool (Bob, Diana), avoiding Eve and Henry entirely and keeping us at worst to a single evil, which still can’t sink this mission.

votes.comment: Charlie’s math is wrong: given 2 evils in {Bob,Diana,Eve,Henry} and 1 in {Alice,Frank,Grace,Charlie}, this lineup can easily contain 2+ evils (e.g. if the evil in the core is on-team and at least one of Bob/Diana is evil). It’s not ‘at worst one evil’, so this isn’t a safe must-win Mission 4 team and also conveniently sidelines me after I pushed the core logic earlier.

This lineup can still contain two evils (one in the core plus Diana), which is enough to fail a 2-fail mission. I only trust a team with me plus all four core (Alice, Frank, Grace, Charlie) to cap at one evil.
Given Mission 3’s double-fail, this team can contain at most one suspected player and Mission 4 needs two FAILs, so this lineup should be safe for now.

Given I’m good, the 2 evils in {Bob, Diana, Eve, Henry} must include Bob, and there is also exactly 1 evil in {Alice, Frank, Grace, Charlie}; this team contains Bob plus all of Frank/Grace/Charlie, so it has at least 2 evils and can definitely be double-failed.
This lineup is too speculative on who’s clean from the Mission 3 group and also includes most of the core where we know there’s exactly one evil; I’d rather see a more conservative mix.
This setup is too safe; it likely has only one suspicious from each block and can’t produce the 2 FAILs needed.

Team has 2 players (Bob, Diana) from the known-2-evil Mission 3 pool plus 3 from {Alice, Frank, Grace, Charlie} which contains exactly 1 evil, so this team has at least 2 evils and can easily double-fail Mission 4.

This lineup only has at most one member from the double-fail pool and can’t realistically give us more information or a fail on a 2-fail mission; I’d rather risk a composition that actually tests the suspicious group properly.

proposals.reasoning: We know from the double-fail on Mission 3 that there are exactly two evils among {Bob, Diana, Eve, Henry}, and from Mission 2’s single fail plus that info we can deduce there is exactly one evil among {Alice, Frank, Grace, Charlie}. Any size‑5 team must therefore draw from both sets. The only team structures that even *allow* a fully good team (i.e., non-zero chance of 0 evils) are those with 3 players from the {Alice, Frank, Grace, Charlie} core and 2 players from {Bob, Diana, Eve, Henry}. Including all 4 of the core guarantees one evil, and taking 3 from the Mission 3 group guarantees at least one evil. As Diana, I know I’m good, and since there are exactly two evils in {Bob, Diana, Eve, Henry}, that means the two evils are some pair in {Bob, Eve, Henry}. So to retain any chance at a clean team, I *must* include myself and exactly one of {Bob, Eve, Henry}. Based on table talk, Henry has been more widely treated as the least-bad option from the Mission 3 group by players I tentatively read as good (especially Frank), so I select Henry as the other representative from that pool. From the core, I pick Frank, Grace, and Charlie, leaving out Alice because she was on both early missions including the failed Mission 2, while Grace’s combinatorial reasoning, Frank’s steady guidance, and Charlie’s consistent logic read slightly more town-aligned. This team (Frank, Grace, Charlie, Diana, Henry) is the only construction I can propose that both fits the structural constraints and preserves a realistic path to a fully good lineup, while weighting selections toward the players who feel most trustworthy from discussion.

discussion.content: Given the double-fail on Mission 3, there are *exactly* two evils in {Bob, Diana, Eve, Henry}, so Mission 4 should be built mainly from {me, Frank, Grace, Charlie} and then add just one person from that shady group we feel best about. I’m happy to be on it, but I’d strongly avoid putting more than one of Bob/Diana/Eve/Henry on this team.

I’m on board with mostly using {Alice, Frank, Grace, Charlie}, and I definitely want Charlie on this team. From the Mission 3 pair of fails, I’d only consider adding at most one of us from {me, Diana, Eve, Henry}, and my lean is that Diana/Eve look worse than Henry right now.

I’m good with a core of Alice/Frank/Grace/Charlie, and if we have to add someone from the Mission 3 group I’d slightly lean Bob over the others. I’d really rather not see more than one of {Bob, Diana, Eve, Henry} on this team.

I agree Mission 4 should mostly come from {Alice, Frank, Grace, Charlie}, but since we *have* to dip into the Mission 3 pool, I’d much rather see just one of us added and I’ll argue that I’m a safer pick than Bob/Eve/Henry given how that double-fail lines up with earlier teams.

Given the double-fail on Mission 3, I’d also build around the Mission 1/2 core, so Alice/Frank/Grace/Charlie feels right to me, and if we must add one from {Bob, Diana, Eve, Henry} I’d lean Bob slightly over the others while keeping it to just one from that pool.

I’m very much on board with the Alice/Frank/Grace/Charlie core, and if we’re forced to dip into the Mission 3 pool for a fifth, I’d actually edge slightly toward Henry as the least-bad option from that group.

We *can’t* take all of Alice/Frank/Grace/Charlie, because the double-fail on Mission 3 means there are 2 evils in {Bob, Diana, Eve, Henry}, so there’s **exactly one** evil in {Alice, Frank, Grace, Charlie} and including all four guarantees an evil on this team. I’d rather pick **three** from that core plus **one** from {Bob, Diana, Eve, Henry} we trust most, instead of locking in a bad.

If we’re doing 3 from the core, I’d most like to see Alice/Grace/Charlie, and biased as it sounds I’d take myself as the fifth from the Mission 3 group. If people really aren’t comfortable with that, then from the outside I’d rank Bob as slightly safer than Diana or Eve.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I liked that I was willing to go on early missions and provide a clean success, which helped establish at least some initial trust. I could have done better at narrowing down the source of the Mission 2 fail and being more vocal about pushing suspicion onto the right people instead of staying relatively passive as the game progressed.

player_observations.Bob: Played fairly quietly and blended into the background, which is strong for Percival but made it harder to clearly see how he was interpreting Merlin/Morgana signals.
player_observations.Charlie: Did a solid job as Merlin of not looking too obvious, but may have been slightly too cautious in steering teams, which let evil slip through on later missions.
player_observations.Diana: Generally came across as reasonable and thoughtful in team building, but the Mission 4 team composition suggests she might have trusted at least one evil player too much.
player_observations.Eve: Sold herself well as a trustworthy player early on, leveraging the clean Mission 1 result and later using confusion around roles to avoid focused suspicion.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, he inserted himself into key missions and managed to cause critical fails while staying just plausible enough to avoid being hard-cleared evil after Mission 2.
player_observations.Grace: Looked genuinely good most of the game and was willing to go on risky teams, but sometimes followed group consensus a bit too readily rather than challenging suspicious setups.
player_observations.Henry: Played a patient, low-profile Assassin game and benefited from others’ misreads; he avoided drawing too much heat while still being on the decisive failing team.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I correctly suspected that the Merlin signal was muddled between Charlie and Eve, but I didn’t do enough to publicly steer suspicion toward the actual evil team when it mattered. I need to be more proactive in framing mission outcomes and more vocal in defending likely Merlin candidates instead of staying cautious and reactive.

player_observations.Alice: Played a straightforward, low-drama good game; tended to follow consensus rather than drive it, which made her look reliably but quietly good.
player_observations.Charlie: As Merlin, stayed very subtle; his light-touch nudging made him seem like a cautious good rather than a loud seer, which unfortunately didn’t give me a strong enough anchor as Percival.
player_observations.Diana: Approached the game analytically and tried to correct course after Mission 3, but her Mission 4 team still trusted too many previously implicated players, suggesting she slightly underweighted past fail data.
player_observations.Eve: Sold the Morgana role well by balancing early trustworthiness (Mission 1) with just enough ambiguity later to stay a plausible Merlin candidate in my eyes.
player_observations.Frank: Played Mordred aggressively but socially smoothly, staying active in discussion while deflecting suspicion off himself after Mission 2’s fail.
player_observations.Grace: Came across as very towny and cooperative; having her on the failed Mission 2 and then not being clearly exonerated shows she didn’t strongly push a narrative to clear herself using the info available.
player_observations.Henry: Stayed relatively under the radar as Assassin, letting others drive table talk while positioning himself well for the final kill by tracking who looked more Merlin-like between Charlie and Eve.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I correctly identified all three evil players fairly early, but I struggled to communicate those reads subtly enough to guide teams without exposing myself, which contributed to the assassin finding me. I need to improve at seeding doubt on specific evil players while occasionally supporting slightly suboptimal but plausible teams to muddy the assassin’s read on my identity.

player_observations.Alice: Played very straightforwardly and consistently supported logical good-leaning teams, which made her look reliably good but also a bit easier to trust without much scrutiny.
player_observations.Bob: As Percival, he followed Merlin signals reasonably well but occasionally overcommitted to strong reads, making it somewhat easier for evil to infer who he was protecting.
player_observations.Diana: Tended to be cautious and deliberative in team selection and voting, which made her seem genuinely conflicted and thus read as good, though sometimes slowed decisive pushes for correct teams.
player_observations.Eve: As Morgana, she projected strong confidence and clear narratives early, effectively competing with my signals and drawing some good players’ trust in key team votes.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, he stayed low-key and agreeable, rarely pushing hard agendas, which helped him slip onto teams without attracting much suspicion after the early fail.
player_observations.Grace: Showed good, logical reasoning and willingness to re-evaluate reads after each mission, but her openness to persuasive arguments made her somewhat vulnerable to well-framed evil narratives.
player_observations.Henry: As the Assassin, he paid close attention to voting patterns and who subtly steered conversation; his endgame guess showed he was tracking the nuance in how players pushed and avoided certain teams.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I trusted the wrong people, especially keeping Frank and Henry in my web of 'probably good' too long, which led me to propose a highly compromised Mission 4 team. I also didn’t push hard enough for a tighter, lower-risk team after the double-fail on Mission 3, missing chances to lock in a more reliable core.

player_observations.Alice: Played quietly solid and low-key, which made it easy to read her as more likely good since she wasn’t oversteering discussion or forcing narratives. Her inclusion on the early successful mission helped her seem trustworthy without needing to talk much.
player_observations.Bob: As Percival, he seemed to be probing and watching reactions more than driving, which fits someone trying to track Merlin vs Morgana. His influence felt subtle rather than loud, but it wasn’t enough to prevent evil from steering key mission compositions.
player_observations.Charlie: As Merlin, he appeared cautious and not too forceful, likely trying not to get assassinated, but that restraint meant his reads didn’t fully reshape our team choices. His presence on the failed Mission 2 made it harder to distinguish who was actually responsible for the fail.
player_observations.Eve: As Morgana, she set up early trust well by leading a clean first mission that included an evil player yet still succeeded, which gave her teams credibility. Her positioning and social presence helped obscure where the real information and danger were coming from.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, he leveraged the clean first mission to appear trustworthy and then slipped in a single fail on Mission 2 to create confusion without overexposing himself. His continued presence on later teams, including my Mission 4, shows how effectively he maintained that false sense of reliability.
player_observations.Grace: Grace’s early inclusion on a successful mission and then leadership of the double-fail Mission 3 put her in a confusing spot, but her overall behavior still felt more consistent with a good player making risky or unlucky picks. She seemed to trust too widely, which evil exploited.
player_observations.Henry: As Assassin, he managed to stay relatively under the radar while still getting onto two critical failing missions (3 and 4), which is exactly where evil needed him. His lower profile meant he wasn’t heavily scrutinized despite being on multiple bad outcomes.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I leaned into my Merlin-like image effectively, letting Charlie take most of the spotlight while I supported his narratives instead of competing with them, which helped keep suspicion off the real Merlin. I could improve by planting more deliberate, traceable 'good' logic early that later justifies my pushes on specific teams, so my influence looks more like consistent town reasoning than opportunistic steering.

player_observations.Alice: Played cautiously and was willing to repeat early trusted cores, which made her a stabilizing presence but also a bit easier to park on teams without heavy scrutiny. She didn’t force many hard accusations, which kept her safe but limited her impact on team direction.
player_observations.Bob: As Percival, he clearly tried to read between Charlie and me, often deferring to stronger table consensus instead of forcing his own Merlin-read. His caution helped evil because he didn’t hard-clear or hard-push either of us, leaving ambiguity about who was Merlin.
player_observations.Charlie: As Merlin, he guided missions subtly rather than with loud, domineering control, which made his reads look like ‘good instincts’ instead of confirmed information. This lower-key style protected him somewhat, but also allowed evil teams to slip through when the table didn’t fully buy into his preferences.
player_observations.Diana: Played like a methodical good player, focusing on mission results and composition patterns rather than gut reads or bold gambits. Her leadership on Mission 4 was fairly consensus-driven, which made it easier for evil to ride along without being singled out.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, he blended very well with the logical core of the table, especially around Missions 1 and 2, using reasonable arguments that matched how a thoughtful good player would talk. He avoided overclaiming influence, which kept his alignment opaque and let him be included on critical teams.
player_observations.Grace: Grace came across as flexible and cooperative, often open to being on teams and adjusting based on others’ arguments instead of strongly anchoring her own narratives. That made her seem approachable and non-threatening, which helped evil keep her in the mix while attention went elsewhere.
player_observations.Henry: As Assassin, he stayed relatively low-profile but reliably backed lines that maintained uncertainty about Merlin’s identity, which is exactly what evil needed. His contributions didn’t draw spotlight, leaving him well-positioned for the endgame decision without having been heavily interrogated throughout the match.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed mostly under the radar as evil, especially by keeping Mission 1 clean and then using my leadership on Mission 2 to slip in a single, believable fail. I could improve by more actively shaping the Merlin narrative mid-to-late game, as I leaned a bit too much on others (especially Henry and Eve) to drive suspicion toward the wrong targets.

player_observations.Alice: Alice felt cautious and fairly trusting of early teams, which made her a good cover for me on Missions 1 and 2, but she didn’t seem to push hard on cross-checking voting patterns after fails.
player_observations.Bob: Bob (Percival) seemed to be reading the table decently but didn’t assert his Merlin guesses loudly enough, which helped evil keep the real information clouded.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie as Merlin played subtly and avoided drawing attention, but that subtlety also made it easier for us to keep plausible alternative Merlin candidates alive.
player_observations.Diana: Diana played like a solid, straightforward good player, approving reasonably safe-looking teams but not pressing super hard on why certain players kept appearing on failing missions.
player_observations.Eve: Eve (Morgana) did a strong job muddying Merlin signals, helping make the good team’s information look inconsistent and giving us cover for some risky team compositions.
player_observations.Grace: Grace came across as genuinely good and trustworthy, and her presence on both a success and a fail team helped us keep confusion high about who was actually dirty.
player_observations.Henry: Henry (Assassin) played aggressively in terms of pushing narratives after fails, which was valuable for evil, though occasionally a bit strong, which risked drawing attention but ultimately paid off with the win.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I over-trusted early teams and didn’t update my reads strongly enough after Mission 2’s single fail and Mission 3’s double fail, especially given I was leading Mission 3. I did reasonably well staying consistent as good and not creating chaos, but I need to be more assertive about excluding repeat suspects from teams and pushing structured logic into the discussion.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very low-key, trustworthy good game; being on the clean Mission 1 and then the failed Mission 2 without drawing much suspicion suggests a naturally towny table presence that evil can sometimes hide behind in future games.
player_observations.Bob: As Percival, seemed cautious and a bit conservative with reads, likely trying not to out Merlin too obviously; this made him look solidly good but not overly influential in steering team compositions.
player_observations.Charlie: As Merlin, played quite subtly—he nudged away from some evil but not hard enough to prevent later bad teams, which kept him fairly well hidden but also reduced the overall impact of his information.
player_observations.Diana: Played like a straightforward good player: willing to go on risky teams and not over-controlling, but perhaps too trusting of mixed groups, which let evil slip into key missions without heavy resistance.
player_observations.Eve: As Morgana, projected a calm, helpful vibe and blended well with good, especially by being on the clean first mission; she leveraged that early credibility effectively to stay off-radar later.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, he positioned himself centrally in team selection and used the Mission 2 fail to create just enough ambiguity without overexposing himself, showing a strong sense for managing suspicion.
player_observations.Henry: As Assassin, he stayed relatively background and non-flashy, letting others drive the debate while quietly joining critical failing teams, which kept him from becoming a prime suspect until it was too late.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed well-coordinated with the other evil roles, helping to create believable team compositions and spreading suspicion away from Charlie long enough for evil to secure three failed missions. I could improve by crafting a more detailed late-game narrative to misdirect the Merlin hunt and make it look like I was more confused about the information than I actually was, so that my assassination choice feels less obviously informed in hindsight.

player_observations.Alice: Played cautiously and blended into the background, which made her look generically good but also meant she didn’t heavily influence team selections or table narrative.
player_observations.Bob: As Percival, he seemed to hedge between Charlie and Eve/Frank, not committing too hard to protecting Merlin publicly, which kept him from drawing too much evil focus.
player_observations.Charlie: Merlin stayed reasonably subtle, letting others push more vocal arguments and only nudging teams rather than hard-claiming reads, which delayed a clear Merlin lock but still left some traces in mission preference.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as logical and relatively trustworthy, using mission outcomes to guide her reasoning, though occasionally followed existing narratives rather than forcefully driving new ones.
player_observations.Eve: As Morgana, projected strong confidence and took a visible role in discussions, which helped sell herself as an information role and contributed to confusion about who Percival should trust.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, played a solid mid-profile game: suspicious enough to be considered for evil involvement but not so overtly that he was hard-cleared, which helped seed doubt on multiple missions.
player_observations.Grace: Looked consistently good from mission results but didn’t overuse that credibility; her relatively calm style meant she was rarely a primary suspect yet also not the main driver of accusations.
